Dear Authors:

Congratulations on the acceptance of your paper for RSP 2009!

Please find the reviewers' comments included in this email. We expect you to revise your paper accordingly and to prepare and upload your camera-ready version by April 4, 2009.

You will soon be contacted by an IEEE representative with instructions of how to prepare your camera-ready papers, and how to submit them.

The page limit for your camera-ready paper is seven (7) pages. An additional page can be added at no cost; if you need this additional page please contact the PC Chairs.

Please note that your paper will be published in the RSP 2009 Proceedings ONLY under the condition that at least one of the co-authors of your paper is fully registered and will present the paper at the conference.

Thank you for your contribution to RSP 2009. We hope for your timely response to the camera ready deadline.

Finally, we look forward to seeing you in Paris. Congratulations again!

Best regards,
Frédéric Rousseau
Ingolf Krueger

(RSP 2009 PC Co-Chairs)



---------------------------------------------

Paper: 63
Title: An Experimental Model-Based Rapid Prototyping Environment for  High-Confidence Embedded Software


-------------------- review 1 --------------------

PAPER: 63
TITLE: An Experimental Model-Based Rapid Prototyping Environment for  High-Confidence Embedded Software

OVERALL RATING: 2 (accept)
REVIEWER'S CONFIDENCE: 3 (high)
Clarity of Problem Definition/Hypothesis: 4 (good)
Overall Presentation (Structure, Language, Figures): 4 (good)
Discussion of Related Work: 4 (good)
Evaluation of the Proposed Approach: 3 (fair)
Adequacy of the Bibliography: 4 (good)

----------------------- REVIEW --------------------

The paper gives a nice overview of a model based software design flow. It supports the following aspects: simulink models, code generation, scheduling analysis, hardware in the loop simulation.

Good well-written overview paper.

Most of the aspects of the design flow is already published. For some of them, e.g. passivity based controller design helps decoupling, the authors even refer to previous work without a clear explanation.
The paper also contain some small typo errors.


-------------------- review 2 --------------------

PAPER: 63
TITLE: An Experimental Model-Based Rapid Prototyping Environment for  High-Confidence Embedded Software

OVERALL RATING: 1 (weak accept)
REVIEWER'S CONFIDENCE: 4 (expert)
Clarity of Problem Definition/Hypothesis: 4 (good)
Overall Presentation (Structure, Language, Figures): 4 (good)
Discussion of Related Work: 2 (poor)
Evaluation of the Proposed Approach: 4 (good)
Adequacy of the Bibliography: 3 (fair)

----------------------- REVIEW --------------------

+ Summary
This paper provides an overview of a rapid prototyping environment
based on MDA principles. The proposed approach relies on Simulink for
the functionnal part, and a DSL for the modeling of architecture. The
toolchain allows for deployment and simulation on hardware.
The approach is interesting, but leaves some questions unanswered:
- Why a DSL, and not using existing standards like AADL or MARTE for
  modeling architecture ? Is it related to the project that exists for
  some time ?
- What about virtual execution on simulators ? In some cases
  (e.g. complete regression testsuite), it proves to be faster, at a
  lower cost while preserving enough functionnal capabilities.
+ Points in favor of acceptance
Good paper, well written, fully in scope
+ Points against acceptance
Authors need to address some bibliiography to be in line with current
practice, and justify their choice.


-------------------- review 3 --------------------

PAPER: 63
TITLE: An Experimental Model-Based Rapid Prototyping Environment for  High-Confidence Embedded Software

OVERALL RATING: 2 (accept)
REVIEWER'S CONFIDENCE: 4 (expert)
Clarity of Problem Definition/Hypothesis: 5 (excellent)
Overall Presentation (Structure, Language, Figures): 4 (good)
Discussion of Related Work: 4 (good)
Evaluation of the Proposed Approach: 4 (good)
Adequacy of the Bibliography: 4 (good)

----------------------- REVIEW --------------------

+ Summary
The paper presents an experimental framework for the rapid prototyping of time-triggered embedded systems oriented to a specific platform,
which allows a hardware-in-the-loop simulation.

+ Points in favor of acceptance
The paper is well written and describes clearly its motivation and
objectives.
The paper presents the design process, including details about the used
tools and
design languages, as the Domain Specific Language ESMoL.
The limitations of the approach are also explicitly stated in the paper,
making clear the kind of analysis that can be performed using the
presented framework.

+ Points against acceptance
The framework is limited to a very specific class of application, i.e.,
time-triggered embedded systems.

Many of the figures are not well described in the text of the paper, and
some
of them are illegible, as for example, Figure 1, 4, and 11.


-------------------- review 4 --------------------

PAPER: 63
TITLE: An Experimental Model-Based Rapid Prototyping Environment for  High-Confidence Embedded Software

OVERALL RATING: 2 (accept)
REVIEWER'S CONFIDENCE: 3 (high)
Clarity of Problem Definition/Hypothesis: 4 (good)
Overall Presentation (Structure, Language, Figures): 4 (good)
Discussion of Related Work: 3 (fair)
Evaluation of the Proposed Approach: 3 (fair)
Adequacy of the Bibliography: 4 (good)

----------------------- REVIEW --------------------

+ Summary
The paper suggests an approach to model-based rapid prototyping environment for embedded software. It is a pragmatic effort to integrate some existing tools/frameworks to accomplish certain prototyping tasks, an approach that becomes quite popular in these days.

+ Points in favor of acceptance
Well known tools like Simulink and GME are integrated in a new tool. The principal features include time schedulers, and hardware-in-the-loop simulation.

+ Points against acceptance
Some Figuers (e.g. Fig. 1, 4 and 5) is hard to read. In the final version the quality of picturtes has to be fixed. The results of experiment should be presentad in a more comprehensive way, with more details about merits and deficiences discovered.
